intro: Sedum mugodscharicum, commonly known as the Karakorum sedum, is a succulent plant native to the high altitudes of Central Asia. It belongs to the Crassulaceae family and is characterized by its fleshy, thick leaves that store water, enabling it to survive in arid environments. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in mountainous regions where temperatures can be extreme. Its flowers are usually small and clustered, appearing in shades of yellow or white, and bloom during the summer months. Sedum mugodscharicum is a hardy species that thrives in full sun and is popular among rock garden enthusiasts.
